GameDBLocalizedString.Text: Tenia del cerdo

Las tenias del cerdo (T. solium) son gusanos planos parasitarios que viven en el sistema digestivo de los humanos. Los cerdos actúan como huéspedes intermediarios cuando consumen comida o agua contaminada con heces humanas. Comer carne de cerdo que no esté cocinada completamente puede causar infección.
Tenia de la vaca

Las tenias de la vaca (T. saginata) son gusanos planos parasitarios que viven en el sistema digestivo de los humanos. Las vacas actúan como huéspedes intermediarios cuando consumen comida o agua contaminada con heces humanas. Comer carne de res que no esté cocinada completamente puede causar infección.
Varicela

La varicela es una enfermedad altamente contagiosa causada por la infección inicial con el virus Varicella zoster. Esta enfermedad resulta en un sarpullido característico en la piel que forma ampollas pequeñas que pican y que eventualmente forman costras.
Culebrilla

La culebrilla es una infección causada por una reactivación del virus Varicella zoster. La enfermedad causa un sarpullido rojo en la piel que forma pequeñas ampollas en forma de cinta, siguiendo el curso de los dermatomas. La culebrilla puede ser extremadamente dolorosa.
Onicomicosis
La onicomicosis o Tinea unguium, es una infección por hongos que afecta los dedos o las uñas de los pies.
Pie de atleta
El pie de atleta, también llamado Tinea pedis, es una infección cutánea en los pies, altamente contagiosa, causada por hongos.
Anemia Ferropénica

La anemia se define como la habilidad reducida de la sangre para transportar oxígeno. Esto puede ser causaro por una disminución en los glóbulos rojos o hemoglobina. La anemia ferropérnica es la forma más común de anemia.
Intolerancia a la lactosa

La intolerancia a la lactosa es la inhabilidad para digerir la lactosa, un azúcar que se encuentra en los productos lácteos. La lactosa no digerida puede causar hinchazón, diarrea, gases o dolor abdominal.
Resfriado común
El resfriado común es una infección viral localizada en la parte superior del sistema respiratorio, normalmente en la nariz o en la garganta.
Sinusitis
La sinusitis se refiere a la inflamación de uno o más senos paranasales. La sinusitis causa inflamación y puede causar drenaje de mucosidades o pus de la cavidad afectada.
Faringitis
La faringitis se refiere a la inflamación de la garganta y puede ser causada por baterias o virus.
Amigdalitis bacteriana
La amigdalitis bacteriana es la infección de las amígdalas. La amigdalitis más común es causada por el Streptococcus pyogenes y se conoce como amigdalitis estreptocócica.
Amigdalitis viral
La amigdalitis viral es una infección de las amígdalas y puede ser causada por varios agentes virales.
Laringitis
La laringitis se refiere a la inflamación de las cuerdas vocales. Puede ser causada por bacterias o virus, pero también por el uso excesivo de la voz.
Influenza
La influenza, conocida normalmente como la 'gripe' es una enfermedad contagiosa común causada por la familia de virus de la influenza.
Bronquitis
La bronquitis es la inflamación de las vías respiratorias inferiores, llamadas bronquios y es usualmente causada por un virus.
Fiebre del heno
La fiebre del heno, conocida en el entorno médico como rinitis alérgica es una inflamación en la nariz causada por la reacción alérgica a un alergeno en el aire, como el polen.
Dermatitis de contacto
La dermatitis de contacto es un sarpullido localizado o irritación de la piel causada por contacto con un alergeno o irritante.
Codo de golfista

El codo de golfista, también conocido como epicondilitis medial, se caracteriza por irradiar dolor desde adentro del codo hacia la muñeca. Esta condición se genera por el movimiento repetitivo, resultando en la irritación de los músculos y tendones de dicho movimiento.
Escoliosis
La escoliosis es la curvatura de la espina dorsal, usualmente en forma de C o de S. Esta condición suele ser indolora.
Síndrome de Raynaud
El síndrome de Raynaud causa adormecimiento y enfriamiento de las manos y dedos (de manos y pies) como respuesta a las bajas temperaturas exteriores.
Síndrome de fatiga crónica
El síndrome de fatiga crónica es una enfermedad muy complicada que se refiere a una condición de fatiga que no puede ser explicada por ninguna condición médica.
Insomnio
El insomnio se define como una experiencia subjetiva de dificultad para dormir. Esto puede ser debido a la inhabilidad de quedarse dormido, dormir continuamente en la noche o levantarse muy temprano.
Contusión de brazo
La contusión de brazo se refiere a la contusión de los tejidos blandos, sin presencia de un hueso fracturado o un daño significativo a la piel o los músculos.
Contusión de mano
La contusión de mano se refiere a la contusión de los tejidos blandos, sin presencia de un hueso fracturado o un daño significativo a la piel o los músculos.
Contusión de pie
La contusión de pie se refiere a la contusión de los tejidos blandos, sin presencia de un hueso fracturado o un daño significativo a la piel o los músculos.
Contusión de tobillo
La contusión de tobillo se refiere a la contusión de los tejidos blandos, sin presencia de un hueso fracturado o un daño significativo a la piel o los músculos.
Contusión de pierna
La contusión de pierna se refiere a la contusión de los tejidos blandos, sin presencia de un hueso fracturado o un daño significativo a la piel o los músculos.
Contusión de pecho
La contusión de pecho se refiere a la contusión de los tejidos blandos, sin presencia de un hueso fracturado o un daño significativo a la piel o los músculos.
Hepatitis A
La hepatitis se refiere a una infección en el hígado. El virus de la hepatitis A se contagia a través de las heces y normalmente ocurre en áreas con baja higiene y sanidad.
Hepatitis B
La hepatitis se refiere a una infección en el hígado. El virus de la hepatitis B se contagia a través de la sangre, contacto sexual o de madre a hijo.
Insuficiencia pancreática exocrina

Pancreatic insufficiency occurs when the gland is damaged enough to seize functioning sufficiently. Normal absorption of nutrients in the small intestine is thus compromised resulting in nutritional deficiencies.
Tiroiditis de Hashimoto
La tiroiditis de Hashimoto es una enfermedad autoinmune donde el sistema inmune gradualmente destruye la glándula tiroides.
Hipotiroidismo
El hipotiroidismo es una enfermedad donde la glándula tiroides funciona en forma inadecuada, produciendo muy poca hormona tiroidea.
Enfermedad de Grave
La enfermedad de Grave es un trastorno endocrino donde la glándula tiroides produce un exceso de hormonas tiroideas.
Esofaguitis
Esophagitis is an inflammation of the oesophageal lining, often caused by acid reflux.
Várices esofágicas
Esophageal varices are abnormally enlarged veins within the esophagus. They are usually caused by portal hypertension due to existing liver disease.
Infección por H. pylori
Helicobacter pylori is a bacteria present in the upper gastrointestinal tract. It is the main cause of peptic ulcers.
Úlcera péptica gástrica
A peptic ulcer is an open lesion in the lining of the stomach, duodenum or esophagus. It is most commonly caused by the bacterium h. pylori or prolonged, excessive use of NSAIDs
Gastritis

Gastritis is an inflammation or erosion of the stomach's lining. It is caused by bad nutrition, or due to excessive alcohol use or excessive use of some medication. Treatment is relatively short and diet modification improves the effectiveness of treatment.
Duodenitis
Doudenitis is an inflammation of the lining of the duodenum; the first part of the small intestine, which is 12 inches long and curved into the C-shape.
Apendicitis
Appendicitis refers to infection in the appendix, which becomes obstructed and swollen. A ruptured appendix can be fatal and thus appendicitis is one of the most common reasons for abdominal surgery.
Enfermedad de Crohn
Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that affects the entire intestine. The exact cause is unknown, however, it is evident that there are genetic, environmental and autoimmune components.
Colitis ulcerativa

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease that produces ulcers in the large intestine. The exact cause is unknown, however, it is evident that there are genetic, environmental and autoimmune components.
Síndrome de colon irritable
Irritable bowel syndrome is chronic gastrointestinal disorder demanding a long term treatment approach. It is not contagious. Diet modification and medicine can usually relieve symptoms.
Gastroenteritis bacteriana
La gastroenteritis bacteriana es una enfermedad gastrointestinal común, que en la mayoría de casos dura unos pocos días.
Fístula intestinal
A fistula is an abnormal anatomical connection between two hollow spaces.
Peritonitis primaria

Primary peritonitis is a bacterial infection of the peritoneum; a membrane covering the inner abdominal wall and organs within the abdominal cavity. Left untreated the condition is almost always fatal.
Fibrosis hepática

Hepatic fibrosis represents an accumulation of scar tissue in the liver. The scar tissue can be the result of long term inflammation or another liver disease caused by viruses, bacterias, malnutrition or alcohol abuse etc. If left untreated it causes cirrhosis.
Cirrosis
Cirrhosis describes a condition where the liver is malfunctioning due to long-term damage; normal liver tissue is replaced with scar tissue.
Cálculos biliares

Gallstones, also called cholelithiasis, are concretions of usually made from bilirubin, bile acids and calcium formed in the gall bladder. Gallstones usually do not cause symptoms, however, if they block the bile duct they can cause a variety of serious conditions.
Colecistitis
Cholecystitis is inflammation and infection of the gallbladder, usually due to blockage of the cystic duct by a gallstone.
Colangitis
Cholangitis is an infection of the bile duct usually caused by bacteria ascending from the duodenum. It occurs usually when the bile duct is already partially blocked by gallstones.
Pancreatitis
Pancreatitis refers to inflammation of the pancreas. It is usually caused by gallstone blockage or excessive alcohol abuse.
Enfermedad celíaca

Coeliac disease is an autoimmune disorder where the immune system reacts to dietary gluten present in wheat, rye and barley. The reaction causes inflammation in the small intestines and thus malabsorption of nutrients.
Glomerulonefritis
Glomerulonephritis refers to inflammation of the filtering unit of the kidneys. It can be caused by an infection or autoimmunity.
Nefritis intersticial
Interstitial nephritis is an inflammation of the interstitial tissue of the kidneys. It can be caused by an infection or as an adverse reaction to medication.
Pielonefritis
Pyelonephritis is inflammation of the kidney, usually due to ascending bacteria spreading up through the urinary tract.
Insuficiencia renal aguda

Acute renal failure refers to an abrupt loss of kidney function, effectively seizing the ability to filter the blood and produce urine. The causes can be many, but are usually due to extensive tissue damage or decreased kidney blood flow.
Insuficiencia renal crónica
Chronic kidney disease refers to a gradual loss of kidney function. The most common cause is untreated diabetes mellitus.
Cálculos renales
Kidney stones, also known as urolithiasis, are usually concretions of calcium. Even though the stones usually pass on their own through the urinary tract, it is an extremely painful condition.
Cálculos ureterales
Stones formed in kidneys usually traveling to kidney tubes and ureters. If they obstruct ureter or just passing through it, they causing unpleasant symptoms.
Cálculos en la vejiga

Bladder stones could be formed in bladder in the process of mineralization of concentrated urine or they could be passing stones from kidneys. Symptoms creating only those that block the the flow of urine.
Infección del tracto urinario (ITU)

UTF, or cystitis, is an infection of the bladder usually by E. coli (E. coli), a type of bacteria commonly found in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract. It is a disease a hundred times more common in women than men.
Cistitis intersticial
Interstitial cystitis is also called Painful bladder syndrome. It is uncertain disease that affects more women than men.
Laceración del hígado
Liver laceration is an injury that occurs when an object pierces the skin and enters a tissue of the body, creating an open wound and liver damage.
Contusión del hígado
Liver contusion is physical trauma to upper abdomen, either by impact, injury or physical attack.
Spleen rupture - blunt
Blunt spleen rupture is caused by impact, injury or physical attack, but with no presence of open wound
Spleen rupture
Penetrating spleen rupture is caused when an object pierces the skin of upper abdomen, causing open wound and wide spleen damage.
Bruised spleen
Also called a spleen contusion is bruising to the spleen after direct impact to upper abdomen. It is less severe than spleen rupture.
Contusión de páncreas
Minor pancreatic contusion without ductal injury with presence of hematoma. It is caused by direct impact without skin laceration.
Pancreas laceration - blunt
Major pancreatic laceration also with duct injury caused by direct impact injury, without open wound in the abdomen.
Pancreas laceration
Massive disruption of pancreatic head caused by penetrating injury to the upper abdomen.
Renal laceration
Major damage to renal parenchyma with presence of retroperitoneal hematoma and open wound in the back.
Contusión renal
Bruising to kidney with or without non-expanding subcapsular hematoma.
Cólera clásico
Cholera is a bacterial disease usually spread through contaminated water supplies. Modern sewage and water treatment eliminated cholera in industrialized countries.
Fiebre tifoidea
Typhoid fever is bacterial disease and spreads through contaminated water and food. Also it is contagious. In industrialized countries it is rare.
Salmonelosis
Salmonella infection is one one of the common bacterial infection that affects human intestinal tract. Human gets infected through contaminated water or food.
Amebiasis
Amoebiasis is caused by Entamoeba histolytica, the infection spreads through water or food contaminated by feces.
Giardiasis
Giardia infection is one of the most common waterborne intestinal infections. Giardias can be transmitted also through personal contact or through food.
Tuberculosis
Tuberculosis of the lungs is highly contagious disease caused by bacteria Mycobacterium tuberculosis affecting principally lungs, but can affect also another organs.
Tularemia

Tularaemia is an infectious disease that affects mainly skin, eyes, lymph nodes and lungs. It is caused by the bacteria known as Francisella tularensis. Tulareamia is highly contagious, potentially fatal, but can be treated effectively.
Ántrax pulmonar

Anthrax is serious infection caused by the bacterium known as Bacillus anthracis. It is spread through the spores, which are usually by animal origin. Contact is made typically by breathing, eating or through the skin lesion.
Fiebre por mordedura de roedores
Rat-bite fever is acute febrile disease caused by bacteria transmitted by rodents, particularly by their urine or mucous secretions.
Enfermedad por razguño de gato

Cat-scratch disease is a common infectious disease caused by Bartonella henselae. It is transmitted through cats, respectively through the cat's scratch or bite. Presence of the bacteria in human is hard to detect by usual methods of cultivation, because growth takes up to 6 weeks.
Pulmonary NTMB infection

Pulmonary mycobacterial infection of nontuberculous type is caused by mycobacterium and it is relatively common. Often occuring in patients with depressed imunity or with preexisting pulmonary disease, but also in healthy patients.
Pertussis (Tos ferina)

Pertussis also known as Whooping Cough is highly contagious respiratory disease. It is caused by bacteria known as Bordetella pertussis. Before development of a vaccine, pertussis was considered a childhood disease. Now it affects people whose immunity has decreased.
Legionnaires disease

Legionnaires disease is caused by the bacterium Legionella pneumophila. The disease is severe form of pneumonia, transmitting through person to person. Untreated Legionnaires diseases has fatal consequences.
Tifus

It is important not to be confused with Typhoid fever. Typhus is caused by the bacteria Rickettsia Typhi, transmitted through various types of fleas. Typhus has been decscribed since 1528. It has sudden onset of various symptoms comparable to flu.
Infectious mononucleosis

Infectious mononucleosis is usually caused by EBV - Epstein-Barr Virus, people usually get infected in the childhood and when they grow up, symptoms will present. There is no vaccine for the disease. In 1920's it was described as "the kissing disease".
Histoplasmosis
Histoplasmosis also called Cave Disease is respiratory disease caused by fungus Histoplasma Capsulatum affecting mainly the lungs. Symptoms vary greatly. Past infection creates partial protection.
Aspergillosis

Aspergillosis is respiratory disease caused by fungus Aspergillus. If patient has weakened immune system, invasive form of the disease spreads through the lungs. Compromised lungs must undergo pulmonary surgery.
American trypanosomias

American trypanosomias also known as Chagas disease is serious inflammatory infectious disease caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. If left untreated, can do serious heart and digestive complications.
Toxoplasmosis
Toxoplasmosis is caused due to the parasite known as Toxoplasma gondii. Symptoms are similar to common flu. Infections is spread through undercooked food, exposure to cat's feces.
Babesiosis
Babesiosis is parasitic disease caused due to the parasite Babesia. It is comparable to malaria. Strain of transmit is through ticks, often presented with Lyme disease.
Lyme disease
Lyme disease is caused by the bite of a deer tick or back-legged tick. It can transfer a form of bacteria Borrelia burgdorferi which directly causes disease.
Hemolytic anemia
Hemolytic anemia happens when there is undergoing hemolysis - abnormal breakdown of red blood cells in the blood vessels or elsewhere in the human body.
Thrombocytopenia
Thrombocytopenia represents a condition with significantly fewer amounts of blood platelets, that are responsible for stopping bleeding by clumping and forming plugs.
Hemofilia
Hemophilia is an inherited disease that causes low levels of clotting factors. Blood then does not clot properly which leads to excessive bleeding.
Talasemia
La talasemia es un desorden sanguíneo hereditario donde se tiene menos hemoglobina y glóbulos rojos.
Sarcoidosis pulmonar

La sarcoidosis es el crecimiento de granulomas (células inflamatorias) en varias partes del cuerpo humano. Muy probablemente es por la reacción inmune a ciertos agentes. No hay cura, pero con medicación de suporte la enfermedad puede pasar.
Sarcoidosis ocular

La sarcoidosis es el crecimiento de granulomas (células inflamatorias) en varias partes del cuerpo humano. Muy probablemente es por la reacción inmune a ciertos agentes. No hay cura, pero con medicación de suporte la enfermedad puede pasar.
Sarcoidosis cardíaca

La sarcoidosis es el crecimiento de granulomas (células inflamatorias) en varias partes del cuerpo humano. Muy probablemente es por la reacción inmune a ciertos agentes. No hay cura, pero con medicación de suporte la enfermedad puede pasar.
Diabetes
Diabetes mellitus refers to a group of diseases that affecting metabolism of glucose. There are many types of diabetes, but generally there is too high level of glucose in blood.
Fibrosis quística
La fibrosis quística es una enfermedad hereditaria que produce daños severos a los pulmones, al sistema digestivo y otros órganos del cuerpo humano.
Otitis externa
La otitis externa es la inflamación de la parte externa del canal auditivo, es causada principamente por bacterias.
Otitis media
Otitis media with effusion is the condition where fluid is present in the middle ear. It usually affects children.
ASOM
Acute suppurative otitis media is a very painful inflammation of the middle ear.
Acute mastoiditis
Mastoiditis refers to infection and inflammation of mastoid cells located in the mastoid process in the temporal bone (beneath the ear).
Otosclerosis
Otosclerosis refers to abnormal hardening of the bone tissue near the middle ear causing inability to transfer sounds from the middle ear to the inner ear; resulting in loss of hearing.
Otorrhea
Otorrhea is basically an inflammation or the ear.
Mumps

Mumps also known as Parotitis, is an inflammatory, infectious disease affecting parotid glands (on one or on the both sides of the human face). Inflammation is caused by bacterial or viral agents. Best prevention is vaccination.
Neumonía
Pneumonia is an infection of the air sacs in the lungs. Pneumonia ranges from mild to life threatening.
Bronconeumonía
Bronchopneumonia is disease from the lung category infections, it is also known as lobular pneumonia. It affects the lungs and bronchi.
Bronchiectasis
Bronchiectasis refers to condition where the large airways in the lungs are damaged.
Simple chronic bronchitis
Chronic bronchitis refers to productive long-lasting cough along with constant irritation of the bronchial lining.
Enfisema
Emphysema refers to a condition when the alveoli - the air sacs - are damaged or destroyed, causing shortness of breath, even in states of relaxation.
COPD
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease - COPD is a chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airways from the lungs.
Asma
Asthma refers to a condition where airways narrow, swell and produce extra mucus. It is a chronic respiratory disease and symptoms may vary from person to person.
Pneumothorax
Collapsed lung also called pneumothorax occurs when air escapes lung filling the space between lung and chest wall, preventing expansion of the affected lung.
Celulitis
Cellulitis is one of the common bacterial skin infections caused mostly by streptococci and staphylococci.
Dermatitis atópica
Atopic dermatitis or eczema refers to a condition that makes skin reddish and itchy. It is chronic skin disease.
Lupus
El lupus es una enfermedad sistémica autoinmune. Es muy difícil de diagnosticar.
Intoxicación por CO
La intoxicación por monóxido de carbono usualmente ocurre por inhalar una gran cantidad de monóxido de carbono.
Chlorine gas poisoning
Chlorine gas poisoning is an illness resulting from the effects of exposure to chlorine beyond the threshold limit value.
Intoxicación por metanol
La ingestión de metanol es una forma poco común de intoxicación que causa perturbaciones metabólicas severas, ceguera, disfunción neurológica permanente y la muerte.
Intoxicación por plomo
La intoxicación por plomo es un tipo de intoxicación por metales causada por la acumulación de plomo en el cuerpo.
Contused lungs
Blunt injury or physical trauma to a body part, either by impact, injury or physical attack. Pulmonary contusion is present.
Pulmonary laceration
Penetrating trauma is an injury that occurs when an object pierces the skin and enters a tissue of the body, creating an open wound. Pulmonary laceration is present.
Síndrome del túnel carpiano
A condition where the median nerve is compressed by surrounding structures when passing through the tunnel near the base of the palm. Pain and disturbed sensation are the main symptoms.
Cubital tunnel syndrome
Cubital tunnel syndrome is caused by the compression of the ulnar nerve in the elbow area.
Artritis reumatoide
Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune disease affecting primarily joints. It typically results in warm, swollen, and painful joints. Pain and stiffness often worsen following rest.
Hip osteoarthritis
Osteoarthritis is a condition where cartilage slowly degenerates and deformities arise in the affected joint. Hip osteoarthritis typically makes walking painful and cumbersome.
Knee osteoarthritis
Knee Osteoarthritis is one of the most common types of arthritis. A slow degradation of the knee cartilage causes pain when walking and stiffness of the joint.
Dermatomyositis
Dermatomyositis is chronic progressive inflammation of the muscles. Symptoms are usually a skin rash and increased muscle weakness over time.
Inclusion-body myositis
Inclusion-body myositis is chronic progressive inflammation and weakening of the muscles. It is most apparent the finger flexor and knee extensor muscles.
Polymyositis
Polymyositis is chronic progressive inflammation and weakening of the muscles. It begins with weakness in the muscles closest to the body trunk from where it spreads.
Spondylolysis
Spondylolysis is a defect, crack or stress fracture in one of the vertebrae, typically in the L5-S1 level. The condition can be painful.
Spondylolisthesis
Spondylolisthesis refers to a displaced vertebrae. Several conditions can cause spondylolisthesis; degenerative changes, trauma, congenital abnormalities, malignancy etc.
Cervical spondylosis
Cervical spondylosis is a degeneration of the cervical spine frmo any cause. Often it is synonymous with age-related wear and tear causing spinal osteoarthritis.
Acute osteomyelitis
Acute osteomyelitis is a bacterial infection of the bone. It can develop into chronic osteomyelitis which is very difficult to treat.
Spinal stenosis

Spinal stenosis refers to an abnormal narrowing of the spinal canal, which affects the spinal cord or nerve roots. It causes pain, discomfort and loss of mobility usually in the limbs corresponding to the level of the stenosis.
Knee bursitis
A bursae is a small fluid filled sac which acts as a cushion between bone and areas prone to friction. Bursitis refers to swelling of said sac caused by inflammation.
Hand bursitis
A bursae is a small fluid filled sac which acts as a cushion between bone and areas prone to friction. Bursitis refers to swelling of said sac caused by inflammation
Osteomalacia
Osteomalacia, known as Rickets if it occurs in childhood, refers to a condition where the bones soften due to impaired bone metabolism.
Tennis Elbow

Tennis elbow, also known as lateral epicondylitis, is characterized by radiating pain from the outside of the elbow to the wrist. The condition is caused by performing repetitive movement and, thus, irritation of the muscles and tendons associated with said movement.
Elbow bursitis
A bursae is a small fluid filled sac which acts as a cushion between bone and areas prone to friction. Bursitis refers to swelling of said sac caused by inflammation.
Herida profunda en mano
A bleeding deep, smooth or jagged wound. It needs suturing.
Herida profunda en brazo
A bleeding deep, smooth or jagged wound. It needs suturing.
Herida profunda en pierna
A bleeding deep, smooth or jagged wound. It needs suturing..
Herida profunda en pie
A bleeding deep, smooth or jagged wound. It needs suturing.
Esguince de hombro

Un esguince es una condición donde un ligamento que rodea una articulación se lleva más allá de su rango normal de acción, causando desgarramientos y en ocasiones la ruptura completa del ligamento afectado.
Dislocación de hombro
Una dislocación, también conocida como luxación, es una condición donde los huesos, conectados por una articulación, se separan de forma anormal. Es frecuente el daño a los tejidos adyacentes.
Esguince de rodilla

Un esguince es una condición donde un ligamento que rodea una articulación se lleva más allá de su rango normal de acción, causando desgarramientos y en ocasiones la ruptura completa del ligamento afectado.
Dislocación de rodilla
Una dislocación, también conocida como luxación, es una condición donde los huesos, conectados por una articulación, se separan de forma anormal. Es frecuente el daño a los tejidos adyacentes.
Esguince de tobillo

Un esguince es una condición donde un ligamento que rodea una articulación se lleva más allá de su rango normal de acción, causando desgarramientos y en ocasiones la ruptura completa del ligamento afectado.
Tobillo dislocado
Una dislocación, también conocida como luxación, es una condición donde los huesos, conectados por una articulación, se separan de forma anormal. Es frecuente el daño a los tejidos adyacentes.
Lesión de LCA

LCA, el ligamento cruzado anterior, es un ligamento ubicado dentro de la articulación de la rodilla que previene el desplazamiento entre los huesos de la pierna. La lesión a este ligamento es común en los deportistas y es causado por una rotación interna anormal.
Fractura simple de cúbito
Fracture of ulna, one of the two bones in the forearm, without damage to the surrounding tissues or breaking of the skin.
Fractura abierta de cúbito

Una fractura abierta, también llamada fractura compuesta es una fractura con termin en una herida abierta, causada por el hueso dislocado, usualmente con el hueso sobresaliendo a través de la herida. El cúbito es uno de los dos huesos en el antebrazo.
Fractura complicada de cúbito
Una fractura complicada consiste en una herida abierta, hueso fracturado dislocado y varios fragmentos del hueso roto.
Fractura simple de radio
Fractura solo del hueso, sin daño a los tejidos cercanos.
Fractura simple de húmero
Fractura solo del hueso, sin daño a los tejidos cercanos.
Fractura abierta de húmero
Una fractura abierta, también llamada fractura compuesta es una fractura con una herida abierta, ruptura de la piel y un hueso fracturado dislocado.
Fractura complicada de húmero
Una fractura abierta, también llamada fractura compuesta es una fractura con una herida abierta, ruptura de la piel y un hueso fracturado dislocado.
Costillas rotas
Fractura simple de una o más costillas sin daño a los tejidos cercanos.
Fractura simple de fémur
Fractura solo del hueso, sin daño a los tejidos cercanos.
Fractura abierta de fémur
Una fractura abierta, también llamada fractura compuesta es una fractura con una herida abierta, ruptura de la piel y un hueso fracturado dislocado.
Fractura complicada de fémur
Una fractura complicada consiste en una herida abierta, hueso fracturado dislocado y varios fragmentos del hueso roto.
Fractura simple de tibia
Fractura solo del hueso, sin daño a los tejidos cercanos.
Fractura abierta de tibia
Una fractura abierta, también llamada fractura compuesta es una fractura con una herida abierta, ruptura de la piel y un hueso fracturado dislocado.
Fractura espiroidea de tibia
Fractura especial espiral del hueso de la tibia, sin daño a los tejidos cercanos.
Fractura simple de tibia
Fractura solo del hueso, sin daño a los tejidos cercanos.
Fractura de tobillo
Fractura de uno o varios huesos del tobillo, sin daño a los tejidos cercanos.
Fractura de huesos metatarsianos
Fractura de uno o más huesos metatarsianos, sin daño a los tejidos cercanos.
Fractura de dedo
Fractura de uno de los huesos de los dedos, sin daño a los tejidos cercanos.
Fractura simple de clavícula
Fractura solo del hueso, sin daño a los tejidos cercanos.
Fractura diafisaria de clavícula
Fractura de la clavícula con una parte dislocada del hueso fracturado
Fractura mandibular
Fractura complicada de la mandíbula, con daño a los tejidos cercanos.
Fractura nasal
Fractura simple de uno o más huesos nasales, con hemorragia presente.
Fiebre reumática aguda
Acute rheumatic fever is an inflammatory disease affecting the heart, muscles, joints and the brain. Usually it develops after a simple streptococcal infection of the throat.
Mitral stenosis
Mitral valve stenosis is a narrowing of the heart's mitral valve, that causes improper opening of the valve and thereby the blood flow through the valve is reduced.
Tricuspid regurgitation
Improper closening of the heart's tricuspid valve, resulting in the regurgitation of blood (blood is pumped backwards, the wrong direction, because the valve can't close properly).
HHD with heart failure
Hypertensive heart disease refers to multiple complications related to high blood pressure that affects the heart and can result in heart failure.
IHD with heart failure
Ischaemic heart disease, also known as coronary artery disease, is large group of cardiovascular diseases caused by the atherosclerosis of the coronary arteries that can result in heart failure.
Hypertensive renal disease
Hypertensive renal disease refers to an increase in systemic blood pressure due to kidney injury or disease.
Angina pectoris
Angina pectoris refers to chest pain caused by insufficient blood flow to the heart muscle. Angina pectoris is often one of the symptoms of coronary artery disease.
Myocardial infarction

Acute myocardial infarction, also known as a heart attack, occurs when blood flow to the myocardium (the muscle tissue of the heart) is blocked. The affected muscle tissue can die and the patient is also at high risk of dying.
Thoracic aortic aneurysm
Thoracic aortic aneurysm refers is a condition where the part of the aorta in the chest cavity is dilated (becomes like a balloon). The aneurysm can rupture and lead to immediate death.
Pulmonary embolism
Pulmonary embolism refers to a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries. The embolism often comes from a dislodged deep venous thrombosis.
Endocarditis
Endocarditis is an infection of the inner lining of the heart. Often the infection arises from bacterial colonization of diseased valves of the heart
Pericarditis
Pericarditis refers to condition where the thin membrane, or sac, surrounding the heart is inflamed.
Myocarditis

Myocarditis is an inflammation of the heart's muscle, also known as myocardium, affecting the ability of the heart to pump blood properly and also the heart's electrical system, potentially giving rise to different arrhythmiaes (irregular and abnormal heart rythms).
Cardiac arrest
Cardiac arrest is the sudden loss of the ability of the heart to pump blood. Cardiac arrest is often the result of acute myocardial infarction or sudden malignant arrythmiaes
CHF
Congestive heart failure where the heart loses its ability to pump a sufficient amount of blood into the body.
Stroke
Stroke occurs when the blood supply to an area of the brain is interrupted or severely reduced, resulting in the death (necrosis) of brain tissue in the affected area.
Atherosclerosis - Carotides

Atherosclerosis is a disease where plaques are built up inside the carotid arteries of the body (the large arteries running from the aorta to the head), hardening and narrowing them, thereby reducing the flow of blood. It could be asymptomatic for decades, symptoms often appear when arteries become more than 50% blocked.
Thrombophlebitis
Thrombophlebitis is condition where the inflammation of veins result in the formation of a blood clot that blocks one or more veins.
Portal vein thrombosis
Portal vein thrombosis refers to a condition where the portal vein (the large vein from the intestines to the liver) is blocked by blood clot.
Pulmonary hypertension
Pulmonary hypertension is hypertension in the arteries from the heart to the lungs. Pulmonary hypertension often happens due to large or many small pulmonary emboli (blood clots in the lungs).
PAD
Peripheral artery disease is caused by a reduced blood flow to the upper or lower limbs due to narrowed arteries, often from artherosclerotic disease.
Mitral valve prolapse

Mitral valve prolapse is a condition where the heart's mitral valve bulges into the left atrium during the contraction of the left ventricle. This is usually following an acute myocardial infarction affecting the attachment of the valve in the left ventricle.
Dilated cardiomyopathy

Dilated cardiomyopathy is a condition where the heart becomes severely enlarged, reducing the ability of the heart to pump, making the heart unable to effectively pump a sufficient amount of blood into the bloodstream.
Giant cells arteritis
Giant cells arteritis is an inflammation of the arterial lining, mainly in the temporal arteries on the side of the head.
Cardiac blunt injury
Cardiac blunt injury is physical trauma to a chest area, resulting in a trauma to the heart.
Flail chest
Flail chest is a life-threatening condition that occurs when a segment of the rib cage breaks due to trauma and moves independently of the rest of the chest wall/ribs during breathing.
Traumatic cardiac arrest

Traumatic cardiac arrest is a condition where the heart has ceased to beat due to blunt or penetrating trauma, such as a stab wound hitting the hard. It is a surgical emergency which will always result in death without immediate surgical care.
Aortic rupture

Traumatic aortic rupture is a condition where the aorta, the largest artery in the body, ruptures as a result of aortic disease (aortic aneurysm, aortic dissection) or trauma to the body. The condition is frequently fatal due to the massive bleeding that results from the rupture.
Tick-borne encephalitis
Tick-borne encephalitis is a viral tick-borne infectious disease involving brain and central nervous system.
Encefalitis
La encefalitis es una inflamación del cerebro, comunmente causada por virus.
Rabia
La rabia es un virus mortal contagiado por la saliva de animales infectados. Su transmisión usualmente es a través de la mordedura del animal.
Pneumococcal meningitis
Pneumococcal meningitis is an inflammation of membranes covering the spinal cord and brain due to the pneumococcal infection.
Staphylococcal meningitis
Staphylococcal meningitis is an inflammation of membranes covering the spinal cord and brain due to the staphylococcal infection.
Migraña
La migraña es un dolor de cabeza severo
Síndrome de Guillain-Barré
El síndrome de Guillain-Barré es una enfermedad seria donde el sistema inmune ataca al propio sistema nervioso.
Neuromyelitis optica
Neuromyelitis optica is an auto-immune disease where the immune system attacks the eye nerves and the spinal cord. A condition that is often seen because of multiple sclerosis.
CIPD

Chronic inflammatory demyelinizating polyneuropathy is an immune inflammatory disease affecting peripheral nervous system by destructing the cover sheet that protect and insulate the nerves and fibres.
Tétano
El tétano es una enfermedad bacteriana seria, que afecta el sistema nervioso y los músculos
Blefaritis
La blefaritis es la inflamación de los párpados.
Conjuntivitis (bacteriana)
La conjuntivitis, conocida como "Ojos rojos" es una enfermedad inflamatoria de la capa más externa de la parte blanca del ojo.
Conjuntivitis (alérgica)
La conjuntivitis, conocida como "Ojos rojos" es una enfermedad inflamatoria de la capa más externa de la parte blanca del ojo.
Open-angle glaucoma
Glaucoma is a disease that results in damage to the optic nerve, because of high pressure inside the eye .
Cluster headache
Cluster headaches are extremely painful headaches, often with crying and a dripping nose, that only occur on one side of the head.
Hypertensive retinopathy
Hypertensive retinopathy is damage to the retina and retina’s blood vessels due to high blood pressure.
Uveitis
Uveitis refers to inflammation of the part of the eye called the uvea. The uvea includes the iris and some adjacent structures.
Scleritis
Scleritis refers to inflammation of the sclera of the eye.
Keratitis - bacterial
Keratitis is an inflammatory disease, mostly caused by bacteria, of the cornea - the clear dome surface of the eye.
Corneal abrasion
Corneal abrasion - known also as scratched eye is one of the most common eye injuries, when foreign obstacles scratches the eye and produce discomfort and related symptoms.
Angle-closure glaucoma
Acute angle-closure glaucoma is caused by sudden and rapid increase of the intraocular pressure.
CRVO
Central retinal vein occlusion is one of the common vascular disorders of the eye's retina.
Conmoción
A concussion is a mild traumatic brain injury resulting in temporary altered mental state and/or loss of function.
Contusión cerebral
Cerebral contusion is a traumatic brain injury usually due to blunt head trauma.
Diffuse axonal injury
Diffuse axonal injury is one of the most common head traumas, it occurs when the brain shifts too quickly inside the skull.
Traumatic brain injury
Occurs when an external force injures the brain. It can be caused by accidents or blunt trauma.
Subdural hematoma

Subdural hematoma is a condition where veins in the subdural space are torn and start to bleed. Blood accumulates in the narrow space which increases the pressure inside the skull cavity. The condition is often fatal if left untreated.
Penetrating trauma - Head
Penetrating head injury is an injury in which the dura mater, the outer layer of the meninges, is breached.
